title: Langton, Calma to lead Indigenous recognition panel
text:
“Today there are almost 800,000 Indigenous Australian voices – from the far reaches of the top end of Australia to inner Sydney," he said.

"I am committed to being the minister for all Indigenous Australians, and want to make sure that all of these voices can be heard loud and clear,”

Proposed models for the voice would be developed with communities across urban, regional and remote areas, he said.

Professor Tom Calma is chancellor of the University of Canberra. Karleen Minney

“The best outcomes are achieved when Indigenous Australians are at the centre of decision‑making. We know that for too long decision-making treated the symptoms rather than the cause.

“It’s time that all governments took better steps to empower individuals and communities, and work in partnership to develop practical and long-lasting programs and policies that both address the needs of Indigenous Australians and ensure that Indigenous voices are heard as equally as any other Australian voice.”

After decades in public life, Professor Langton was a member of the previous expert panel on constitutional recognition, established in 2012, and has been appointed as Melbourne University's first associate provost.

Professor Calma is chancellor of the University of Canberra and a former race discrimination commissioner and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander social justice commissioner.

The Coalition will spend $7.3 million on the co-design process.

The new senior advisory group will include up to 20 leaders and experts from across the country.

Enshrined voice or symbolic recognition?

Mr Wyatt wants the government to consider a series of propositions related to constitutional recognition, including the voice to Parliament and mechanisms for "truth telling".

His move to return the Indigenous voice to the national political agenda in July sparked a conservative backlash within the government.

A referendum before the next federal election, due by 2022, will instead provide for symbolic recognition of Indigenous Australians in the constitution.

Labor's spokeswoman Linda Burney said last week the opposition would persist in seeking a bipartisan position on the voice and constitutional recognition.

The chairman of Prime Minister Scott Morrison's Indigenous advisory council, Wiradjuri man Roy Ah-See, has described a constitutionally enshrined voice as the only meaningful form of Indigenous recognition.
description: Indigenous Australians Minister Ken Wyatt has appointed the two respected academics to lead a co-design process for a legislated voice to Parliament.
